task.Question: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

Annotator Metadata.Steps:
1. I did a search for Mercedes Sosa
2. I went to the Wikipedia page for her
3. I scrolled down to "Studio albums"
4. I counted the ones between 2000 and 2009

steps.content: How many studio albums were published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009 (included)? You can use the latest 2022 version of english wikipedia.

steps.reasoning:
1. Perform a WebSearch to find the latest version of Mercedes Sosa's discography on Wikipedia, specifically looking for her studio albums released between 2000 and 2009.

2. If the search yields a relevant Wikipedia page, open the page in the Browser tool to locate the section detailing her studio albums.

3. Review the list of studio albums to identify which ones were released between 2000 and 2009.

4. Count the number of studio albums found in that time frame.

5. If no relevant information is found in the initial search, consider searching for other reliable music databases or websites that may provide her discography for the specified years. 

6. Compile the final count of studio albums released by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009.

1. Specific facts or figures given in the request: 
   - The time frame of 2000 to 2009 (inclusive).
   - The subject is Mercedes Sosa and her studio albums.

2. Facts that may need to be looked up and where to find them:
   - The number of studio albums published by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009, which can be found on the latest version of her discography on English Wikipedia.

3. Facts that may need to be derived:
   - The total count of studio albums released by Mercedes Sosa within the specified time frame after identifying them.

4. Facts that are recalled from memory, hunches, well-reasoned guesses, etc.:
   - No specific facts are recalled; the information is expected to be found through the search.

      Haydée Mercedes
      "
      La Negra
      "
      Sosa
      (
      Latin American Spanish:
      
      BID:729 link [meɾˈseðes ˈsosa], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Help:IPA/Spanish'
      ; 9 July 1935
      superscript
        BID:732 link [1], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-birth-1'
      – 4 October 2009) was an
      BID:735 link Argentine, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentines'
      singer who was popular throughout
      BID:736 link Latin America, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America'
      and many countries outside the region. With her roots in
      BID:737 link Argentine folk music, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Folk_music_of_Argentina'
      , Sosa became one of the preeminent exponents of
      El nuevo cancionero
      . She gave voice to songs written by many Latin American songwriters. Her music made people hail her as the "voice of the voiceless ones".
      superscript
        BID:740 link [2], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-tmc-2'
      She was often called "the conscience of Latin America".
      superscript
        BID:744 link [3], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-3'
    
      Sosa performed in venues such as the
      BID:748 link Lincoln Center, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center'
      in New York City, the
      BID:749 link Théâtre Mogador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador'
      in Paris, the
      BID:750 link Sistine Chapel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel'
      in Vatican City, as well as sold-out shows in New York's
      BID:751 link Carnegie Hall, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall'
      and the Roman
      BID:752 link Colosseum, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum'
      during her final decade of life. Her career spanned four decades and she was the recipient of six
      BID:753 link Latin Grammy, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy'
      awards (2000, 2003, 2004, 2006, 2009, 2011), including a
      BID:754 link Latin Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Lifetime_Achievement_Award'
      in 2004 and two posthumous
      BID:755 link Latin Grammy Award for Best Folk Album, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_Grammy_Award_for_Best_Folk_Album'
      in 2009 and 2011. She won the
      BID:756 link Premio Gardel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premios_Gardel'
      in 2000, the main musical award in Argentina. She served as an ambassador for
      BID:757 link UNICEF, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNICEF'
      .
    heading Life
      Life
    ​
    [
    BID:763 link edit, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Mercedes_Sosa&action=edit&section=1'
    ]
    
      Sosa was born on 9 July 1935, in
      BID:767 link San Miguel de Tucumán, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/San_Miguel_de_Tucum%C3%A1n'
      , in the
      BID:768 link northwestern Argentine, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Argentine_Northwest'
      province of
      BID:769 link Tucumán, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province'
      , of
      BID:770 link mestizo, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mestizo'
      ancestry. She was of French, Spanish and
      BID:771 link Diaguita, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diaguita'
      descent.
      superscript
        BID:773 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      Her nickname "la negra", which is a common nickname in Argentina for people with darker complexion, is a reference to her indigenous heritage.
      superscript
        BID:777 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      Her parents, a day laborer and a washerwoman,
      superscript
        BID:781 link [6], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-6'
      were
      BID:784 link Peronists, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronism'
      , although they never registered in the party, and she started her career as a singer for the
      BID:785 link Peronist Party, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peronist_Party'
      in
      BID:786 link Tucuman, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tucum%C3%A1n_Province'
      under the name Gladys Osorio.
      superscript
        BID:788 link [7], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-7'
      In 1950, at age fifteen, she won a singing competition organized by a local radio station and was given a contract to perform for two months.
      superscript
        BID:792 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      She recorded her first album,
      BID:796 link La Voz de la Zafra, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_voz_de_la_zafra'
      , in 1959.
      superscript
        BID:798 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      A performance at the 1965
      BID:801 link Cosquín National Folklore Festival, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cosqu%C3%ADn_Festival'
      —where she was introduced and brought to the stage while sitting in the audience by fellow folk singer
      BID:802 link Jorge Cafrune, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Cafrune'
      —
      superscript
        BID:804 link [9], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-test-9'
      brought her to the attention of the Argentine public.
      superscript
        BID:808 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      Sosa and her first husband,
      BID:811 link Manuel Oscar Matus, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Manuel_Oscar_Matus&action=edit&redlink=1'
      , with whom she had one son, were key players in the mid-60s
      BID:813 link nueva canción, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nueva_canci%C3%B3n'
      movement (which was called
      nuevo cancionero
      in Argentina).
      superscript
        BID:816 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      Her second record was
      Canciones con Fundamento
      , a collection of Argentine folk songs.
    figure
      BID:821 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa,_F%C3%A9lix_Luna_y_Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa with
        BID:824 link Félix Luna, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna'
        and
        BID:825 link Ariel Ramírez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez'
        (at the piano)
    
      Sosa "spent the late 1960s building her audience in Europe and among the cosmopolitan middle class in Buenos Aires, becoming in the process a much bigger star" than her contemporaries.
      superscript
        BID:828 link [11], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-11'
      In 1967, Sosa toured the United States and Europe with great success.
      superscript
        [
        BID:833 link citation needed, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed'
        ]
      In later years, she performed and recorded extensively, broadening her repertoire to include material from throughout Latin America.
    
      In the early 1970s, Sosa released two concept albums in collaboration with composer
      BID:836 link Ariel Ramírez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ariel_Ram%C3%ADrez'
      and lyricist
      BID:837 link Félix Luna, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A9lix_Luna'
      :
      Cantata Sudamericana
      and
      Mujeres Argentinas
      (Argentine Women). She also recorded a tribute to Chilean musician
      BID:840 link Violeta Parra, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Violeta_Parra'
      in 1971, including what was to become one of Sosa's signature songs,
      BID:842 link Gracias a la vida, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gracias_a_la_vida'
      .
      superscript
        BID:844 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      superscript
        BID:848 link [12], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-ap-12'
      She further popularized of songs written by
      BID:851 link Milton Nascimento, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Milton_Nascimento'
      of Brazil and
      BID:852 link Pablo Milanés, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pablo_Milan%C3%A9s'
      and
      BID:853 link Silvio Rodríguez, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Silvio_Rodr%C3%ADguez'
      both from
      BID:854 link Cuba, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cuba'
      .
      superscript
        BID:856 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      Throughout the decade, she released albums such as
      Hasta la Victoria
      in 1972 and
      Traigo un Pueblo
      
      en mi Voz
      in 1973. They featured songs like "Cuando tenga la tierra", written by
      BID:862 link Ariel Petrocelli, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ariel_Petrocelli&action=edit&redlink=1'
      and Daniel Toro, which tackles political and social issues like wealth and land inequality.
      superscript
        BID:864 link [13], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13'
      superscript
        BID:868 link [14], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-14'
      During the 1970s she was a part of two films by the director
      BID:871 link Leopoldo Torre Nilsson, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopoldo_Torre_Nilsson'
      :
      BID:873 link El Santo de la Espada, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/El_Santo_de_la_Espada'
      in 1970 and
      BID:875 link Güemes, la tierra en armas, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G%C3%BCemes:_la_tierra_en_armas'
      in 1971, in which she portrayed
      BID:876 link Juana Azurduy de Padilla, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juana_Azurduy_de_Padilla'
      , the guerrilla military leader who fought for Argentine independence.
      superscript
        BID:878 link [13], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:2-13'
      superscript
        BID:882 link [15], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-15'
    figure
      BID:886 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa_2.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1972
    
      After the
      BID:890 link military junta, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Reorganization_Process'
      of
      BID:891 link Jorge Videla, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Videla'
      came to power in 1976, the atmosphere in Argentina grew increasingly oppressive. Sosa faced death threats against both her and her family, but refused for many years to leave the country. At a concert in
      BID:892 link La Plata, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_Plata'
      in 1979, Sosa was searched and arrested on stage, along with all those attending the concert.
      superscript
        BID:894 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      Their release came about through international intervention.
      superscript
        BID:898 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      Despite attempts to hold more concerts, she was officially barred from performing by the military regime.
      superscript
        BID:902 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      Banned in her own country, she moved to Paris and then to
      BID:905 link Madrid, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Madrid'
      .
      superscript
        BID:907 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      superscript
        BID:911 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      She has spoken publicly about her artistic and emotional struggles during this period of her life.
      superscript
        BID:915 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
      While in exile, she released the album
      A Quien Doy
      in 1981. The album included a recording of the song "Cuando Me Acuerdo de Mi Pais" which was originally written by the prolific Chilean singer/songwriter,
      BID:919 link Patricio Manns, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patricio_Manns'
      . The song, which he wrote while also in political exile, expresses the sorrow he felt from being separated from his homeland.
      superscript
        BID:921 link [16], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-16'
      She related to this feeling and struggled to continue recording and performing. In an interview with the New York Times, she said, “It was a mental problem, a problem of morale...It wasn’t my throat, or anything physical".
      superscript
        BID:925 link [5], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:0-5'
    
      Sosa returned to Argentina from her exile in Europe in February of 1982,
      superscript
        BID:930 link [17], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17'
      superscript
        BID:934 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      several months before the military regime collapsed as a result of the
      BID:937 link Falklands War, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falklands_War'
      , and gave a series of concerts at the
      BID:939 link Teatro Ópera, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Teatro_Opera'
      in Buenos Aires, where she invited many of her younger colleagues to share the stage. A double album of recordings from these performances became an instant best seller. She then traveled to perform in her home province of Tucuman. However, these performances were largely ignored by mainstream media in the country.
      superscript
        BID:941 link [17], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-:1-17'
      In subsequent years, Sosa continued to tour both in Argentina and abroad, performing in such venues as the
      BID:944 link Lincoln Center, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lincoln_Center'
      in New York City and the
      BID:946 link Théâtre Mogador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre_Mogador'
      in Paris. In poor health for much of the 1990s, she performed a comeback show in Argentina in 1998.
      superscript
        BID:948 link [8], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Mercedes_Sosa:_Obituary-8'
      In 1994, she played in the
      BID:951 link Sistine Chapel, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sistine_Chapel'
      in Vatican City.
      superscript
        BID:953 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
      In 2002, she sold out both
      BID:956 link Carnegie Hall, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carnegie_Hall'
      in New York and the
      BID:957 link Colosseum, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colosseum'
      in Rome in the same year.
      superscript
        BID:959 link [4], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Legendary_folk_singer_Mercedes_Sosa_dies_at_74-4'
    figure
      BID:963 link, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mercedes_Sosa.jpg'
      Figcaption
        Sosa in 1973
    
      A supporter of
      BID:967 link Perón, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Juan_Per%C3%B3n'
      , she favored leftist causes throughout her life. She supported President
      BID:968 link Raul Alfonsin, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ra%C3%BAl_Alfons%C3%ADn'
      in the election of 1983 which marked the return of democracy in Argentina following the dictatorship. She referred to this election as "Argentina's Spring"
      superscript
        BID:970 link [18], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-18'
      She opposed President
      BID:973 link Carlos Menem, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carlos_Menem'
      , who was in office from 1989 to 1999, and supported the election of
      BID:974 link Néstor Kirchner, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/N%C3%A9stor_Kirchner'
      , who became president in 2003.
      superscript
        BID:976 link [19], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-19'
      Sosa was a
      BID:979 link UNESCO Goodwill Ambassador, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UNESCO_Goodwill_Ambassador'
      for Latin America and the Caribbean.
      superscript
        BID:981 link [10], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-Latin_artist_Mercedes_Sosa_dies-10'
      superscript
        BID:985 link [20], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-20'
    
      Sosa disliked being identified as a protest singer.
      superscript
        BID:990 link [21], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-21'
      superscript
        BID:994 link [22], url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mercedes_Sosa#cite_note-22'
      While she was outright in her political stances, Sosa said the following on the position of the artist:
    blockquote
      
        “An artist isn’t political in the party political sense – they have a constituency, which is their public – it is the poetry that matters most of all.”
    
      In a career spanning four decades, she worked with performers across several genres and generations, folk, opera, pop, rock, including
      BID:1001 link Martha Argerich, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martha_Argerich'
      ,
      BID:1002 link Andrea Bocelli, url='https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrea_Bocelli'
      ,

steps.overview: Identified two studio albums released by Mercedes Sosa between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' (2005) and 'Cantora 1' (2009), and 'Cantora 2' (2009) which is a collaborative album.
steps.long_answer: Mercedes Sosa released three studio albums between 2000 and 2009: 'Corazón Libre' in 2005, and two albums titled 'Cantora 1' and 'Cantora 2' in 2009, both featuring various artists.
